OOC: The hole is fine with me.  I think i have a big say in this, 
because it was me and Soulstice who contained Skulletron.

--- In nbwrpg@y..., "LurkerAbyss" <1641coburn@h...> wrote:
> OOC: Sorry if the hole is a mode, I needed someway for the spark to 
get out!  The first part is sort of an introduction, the part after 
the line is the first time of me actually using him.  And a big 
appology for violence against rabbits!
> 
>     A dim, ex-Alliance spark is buried in a dark, Maximal storage 
place.  The spark was that of the one and only Skulletron.  It 
started to light up a bit.  Then, it started to float.  It flew 
around a little bit, then saw a hole, big enough for it to get 
outside.  It flew out, and flew all over.  Then, it disappeared in a 
small explosion of light.  It was heading towards the Matrix.  
Skulletron's spark got closer, and closer.  Then, the Matrix spoke.
> 
>     "Hideous spark!  I can not take you, Skulletron, and I won't.  
Now, I must ban you from here, and I shall send you away to the Vok," 
the Matrix's voice said.
> 
>      Skulletron's spark was sent to a Vok colony way out in space.  
They took his spark, and began making an organic creature out of 
him.  They made him a gruesome killing machine.  And they named him 
Slaughter.  Slaughter still had the mind and memories of Skulletron.  
Revenge.  Slaughter had to eat everything he killed, to live.  If he 
didn't eat within 2 days, he would die.  He even ate energon and 
sparks.  The Vok were satisfied with their creation, and sent him to 
Earth.  Slaughter appeared in Canada.
> ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
>          Slaughter was in a dense forest.  He looked around.  A 
rabbit!  Slaughter ran over, then did a somersault and landed in 
front of the rabbit.  The rabbit stared up at him, and vice-versa.  A 
drop of slime dropped from Slaughter's chin and landed on the 
rabbit's head, and the rabbit blinked, then tried rubbing the slime 
off.  Slaughter picked up the rabbit by its neck with his pinsir, 
then crammed the rabbit into his mouth, and chewed vigorously.  The 
crunching of bones and guts could be heard.  Then, Slaughter was 
finished his meal.  Some blood still dripped from the sides of his 
mouth, but he didn't bother to wipe it, and let it drip.  Slaughter 
flapped his wings and flew up over the trees.  Then, he began flying 
off, looking for a bigger meal.
